Hypothesis Test



The use of probability theory and statistics to decide 2 competing options while recognizing the randomness of data.







Null hypothesis \((H_0)\): a statement of the status quo, i.e., nothing interesting is going on.
Alternative hypothesis \((H_1)\): a theory that interests you before any data are collected.





New Medication üíä


\(H_0\): Ineffective
\(H_1\): Effective





Criminal Trial üöî


\(H_0\): Not guilty
\(H_1\): Guilty

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
How do we decide?


Let‚Äôs take 1-sample Z-test as an example
hold for other HT
In order to determine whether our observations make sence under H_0
we need to know what‚Äôs normal under H_0
To this end, we will need something called the Test Stat
The null distribution of Test Stat can help us determine what‚Äôs normal and what isn‚Äôt
In this case, what distribution does Z have under H_0?
Pair up with your neighbors and discuss
Regroup in 30s to share your ideas



Suppose \(X_1, \ldots, X_n \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} N(\mu, \sigma^2)\), where \(\sigma^2\) is known. Want to test
\[H_0: \mu = \mu_0 \quad\text{vs}\quad H_1: \mu > \mu_0\] at \(\alpha\) level of significance (say \(\alpha=0.05\)).


Test Statistics
\[Z = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \class{fragment}{\overset{H_0}\sim N(0, 1)}\]

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
How do we decide?


The alternative tells us what‚Äôs intereting to us
In this case, the greater than alternative indicates that we are interested in large values of mu
So we reject H_0 when we observe large test statistics


Suppose \(X_1, \ldots, X_n \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} N(\mu, \sigma^2)\), where \(\sigma^2\) is known. Want to test
\[H_0: \mu = \mu_0 \quad\text{vs}\quad \class{green-box}{H_1: \mu > \mu_0}\] at \(\alpha\) level of significance (say \(\alpha=0.05\)).
Test Statistics
\[Z = \frac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \overset{H_0}\sim N(0, 1)\]
Decision Rule

Reject \(H_0\) if \(z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} \geq z_{\alpha}\)
Fail to reject \(H_0\) if \(z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}} < z_{\alpha}\)

A visualization of the rejection region

section: How likely is a Type I Error?
text:
How likely is a Type I Error?



\[
\begin{align}
  P(\text{Type I Error})
    &= P(\text{reject } H_0 \mid H_0 \text{ is true}) \\[3px]
    &= P(Z \geq z_\alpha \mid Z \sim N(0,1))          \\[3px]
    &= \alpha
\end{align}
\]







Theorem


\[P(\text{Type I Error}) = \alpha \qquad \forall \, \text{HT}\]


Directly control Type I Error rate via significance level \(\alpha\)













Pop Quiz ü§î


Can we set \(\alpha\) to 0?

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
Let‚Äôs say you can generate samples from the null distribution
and perform as many HT as you wish
how would you estimate P(Type I Error)?
count how many tests would wrongfully reject H_0









Rejection Rule for \(H_1: \mu > \mu_0\)


\[z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \geq z_{\alpha}\]






set.seed(123)

# Initialize parameters
mu0 <- 0               # H_0: mu = 0
sigma <- 1; n <- 50    # sd and sample size
alpha <- 0.05          # significance level
z_alpha <- qnorm(alpha, lower.tail = F)  # ~1.65
n_rej <- 0

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
Rejection Rule for \(H_1: \mu > \mu_0\)


\[z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \geq z_{\alpha}\]





set.seed(123)

# Initialize parameters
mu0 <- 0               # H_0: mu = 0
sigma <- 1; n <- 50    # sd and sample size
alpha <- 0.05          # significance level
z_alpha <- qnorm(alpha, lower.tail = F)  # ~1.65
n_rej <- 0

# Conduct 10000 HT
for (i in 1:10000) {
  x <- rnorm(n, mu0, sigma)                # H_0 is true: X ~ N(0,1)
  z <- (mean(x) - mu0) / (sigma / sqrt(n)) # observed test statistics
  if (z >= z_alpha) n_rej <- n_rej + 1     # count rejections
}

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
Rejection Rule for \(H_1: \mu > \mu_0\)


\[z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \geq z_{\alpha}\]





set.seed(123)

# Initialize parameters
mu0 <- 0               # H_0: mu = 0
sigma <- 1; n <- 50    # sd and sample size
alpha <- 0.05          # significance level
z_alpha <- qnorm(alpha, lower.tail = F)  # ~1.65
n_rej <- 0

# Conduct HT for 10000 times
for (i in 1:10000) {
  x <- rnorm(n, mu0, sigma)                # H_0 is true: X ~ N(0,1)
  z <- (mean(x) - mu0) / (sigma / sqrt(n)) # observed test statistics
  if (z >= z_alpha) n_rej <- n_rej + 1     # count rejections
}

# Estimated P(Type I Error)
n_rej / 10000

[1] 0.0478


Very close to \(\alpha = 0.05\)!

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
How should we interpret \(\alpha\)?


what gives?
although having a observed test statistics larger than z_0.05 is uncommon
it‚Äôs not impossible
in these rare instances, we would think H_1 makes more sence
but in fact, H_0 is true









Interpretation


If \(H_0: \mu = 0\) were true, there is a 5% chance that the HT procedure will lead to the conclusion of

‚ÄúReject \(H_0\)‚Äù

title: Type I and II Errors
section: How likely is a Type II Error?
text:
How likely is a Type II Error?


but what does it really mean?
it means that X_bar ~ N(mu_1, sigma^2)









Rejection Rule for \(H_1: \mu > \mu_0\)


\[z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \geq z_{\alpha}\]





\[P(\text{Type II Error})= P(\underbrace{\text{fail to reject } H_0}_{(1)} \mid \underbrace{H_1 \text{ is true}}_{(2)})\]


When would we ‚Äúfail to reject \(H_0\)‚Äù ? \(\implies\) \(z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} < z_\alpha\)
What does ‚Äú\(H_1\) is true‚Äù mean? \(\implies\) \(\mu = \mu_1\), where \(\mu_1\) is a number \(> \mu_0\)

\[\frac{\bar{X} - \mu_1}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} \overset{H_1}{\sim} N(0, 1)\]

title: Type I and II Errors
section: How likely is a Type II Error?
text:
How likely is a Type II Error?


Deconstruct the complex test stat to simpler RV
Reconstruct to a nice RV



\[
\begin{align}
  P(\text{Type II Error})
    &= \class{fragment}{P(\text{fail to reject } H_0 \mid H_1 \text{ is true})} \\[3px]
    &\class{fragment}{{} = P\left(\frac{\bar{X} - \mu_0}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} < z_\alpha \mid \mu = \mu_1\right)}         \\[3px]
    &\class{fragment}{{} = P\left(\bar{X} - \mu_0 < z_\alpha \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \mid \cdots\right)}       \\[3px]
   &\class{fragment}{{} = P\left(\bar{X} < \mu_0 + z_\alpha \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \mid \cdots\right)}       \\[3px]
   &\class{fragment}{{} = P\left(\bar{X} - \mu_1 < \mu_0 - \mu_1 + z_\alpha \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \mid \cdots\right)}       \\[3px]
   &\class{fragment}{{} = P\Bigg(\underbrace{\frac{\bar{X} - \mu_1}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}}_{\class{fragment}{\overset{H_1}{\sim} N(0,1)}} < \underbrace{\frac{\mu_0 - \mu_1}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}} + z_\alpha}_{\class{fragment}{\text{constant}}} \mid \cdots\Bigg)}       \\[3px]
   &\class{fragment}{{} = \beta \quad\text{by looking up } Z \text{ table}}
\end{align}
\]

# Theoretical beta
pnorm((mu0 - mu1)/(sigma / sqrt(n)) + z_alpha)

Seems correct! üíØ

title: Type I and II Errors
text:
How do we interpret \(\beta\)?


We picked z_0.05 based on H_0
Now that H_1 is true
faiure to reject H_0 will lead to a wrong conclusion
That is, any observed test statistics to left of z_0.05
will result in a Type II error









Interpretation


If \(H_1: \mu = 0.3\) were true, there is a 31.7% chance that the HT procedure will lead to the conclusion of

‚ÄúFail to reject \(H_0\)‚Äù

\(P(\text{Type I Error})\) is always \(\alpha\)
\(P(\text{Type II Error})\) or \(\beta\) depends on many factors

\(\alpha\)
\(n\) and \(\sigma\)
